captions.text:
- Oh my God, you guys
are so Asian right now.

- No, I mean like where
are your parents from?

- You know, you're
pretty tall for an Asian.

- No, where are you
parents' ancestors from?

- I just wanted to introduce
you to Eugene over here.

- Yeah, well Stacy's
really into Asian guys
so I figured it'd be a nice...

- It is so nice to finally
meet your girlfriend!

- Yeah, so me and my friend
were at 99 Ranch and-
- You don't know what 99 Ranch is?
- Oh, it's that new bar, right?
- Um, I don't speak Min, do you?
- You know my cousin's wife is Oriental.
- Are you North or South Korean?
- Because I'm not trapped in North Korea.

- The Orient, ah, so we're
in the 1950's right now.
- How do I change this setting?
- Yeah, I just got this phone.

- So my mom was like (with
Asian accent) "Eugene
That feels like a little bit racist.
you wanted to go into entertainment?
- Of course 'cause I'm Asian you think
that my parents want me to be a doctor

- OK, that's like a little
racist, but it's cool.

- So she was like (with
Asian accent) "oh, Eugene"-
- No, no, you can't do it though.
- Oh, I wasn't tryin' to be offensive,

it's good that they're
cool with it, though.
- Nah, they wanted me to be a doctor.
- Yeah Mom, that was my new girlfriend.
- I'm so glad I have minority friends.
All my pictures are with White people.

- Uh, you know, technically
Asians are the majority.

There are literally
billions of us in the world.
- Oh my God, I love that new HBO show.
- Yeah, there are no Asians on it.
- Yeah, but there are two Black people!
- Are we all in the frame?

- [Voiceover] Yeah,
you're on, you're all in.
If we had a baby together, it would be

the most beautiful half-Asian
baby in the entire world.
- It would totally be half Asian.

- Dude, in general half-Asian
people are the most beautiful.

- Oh my God, I had the
best pho last night.
As an Indian, where was the rest of Asia?

- I went with my girlfriend
Tammy Nguyen, do you know her?

- I don't know, I think
probably around eight o'clock.

- So, you might wanna
think about that next time
- I am the great, stolen Dragon!

comments.text:
I'm a Finnish-swede, which basically means i was born in Finland and i've 
lived here all my life but my mother tongue is Swedish. However, most "real 
Finns" don't seem to understand this (it's crazy complicated right. right?) 
so I have to explain this almost every time i meet a new person, and they 
still go "so that means you're Swedish, right?" 99.9% of them also say "omg 
I SUCK at Swedish". Like reaaaaally i've totally never heard that before .'﻿
comments.author: banina

comments.text:
I'm brazilian, half-Japanese. My grandpa and my grandma's parents are from 
Japan. But my mom is totally brazilian, my family is almost all black 
(except for my mom and my aunt) and I even have Indians in some point of my 
family. 
So I'm basically a tanned Japanese. I looked like an indian when I was a 
kid because I had really Japanese eyes. More than now. So my friend called 
me "Tainá", because there's this movie about an Indian called Tainá. 
Today I don't have those Asian things. The only Asian thing that remains 
today is my nose. My eyes are almost Brazilian now.﻿

comments.author: SarahTheYoutuber

comments.text:
My grandmother is Japanese and she still refers to herself as Oriental (she 
immigrated to the U.S in the early 1950s). My mother (half-Japanese) uses 
the term as well due to my grandmothers usage. I think it's more of an 
archaic and outdated word than anything meant to be offensive.

Also, my husband is Korean and he didn't really understand/wasn't offended 
by anything in this video. He even chalked up the south/north Korean 
comment to Korea being a small country and so he understands why many 
people are confused. Granted he was born in and has spent the vast majority 
of his life here in Korea, so he hasn't been exposed to the same 
questions/comments over and over again; his views might change a bit once 
we spend more time in the U.S (moving there this summer).﻿

comments.author: Frvncis

comments.text:
As a Filipino born and raised in Southern Texas, I had to deal with alot of 
these. Some of the common misconceptions were:
-Asia was a country itself (so apparently people thought I was stupid when 
i said i was full Filipino and Asian)
-I was born in Asia.
-The Philippines was in Mexico so there was no way I was Asian.
-I knew Chinese, Japanese, or Korean.﻿

comments.author: Brawlee Sedore

comments.text:
I see this comment isn't anywhere (or maybe I just missed it), so I think 
I'll post it just in case anyone didn't understand. At the joke at 2:41, 
where the guy was talking about going with his girlfriend "Tammy Nguyen", 
and the reply is "when" it's because Nguyen is pronounced "Win" or "Wen" 
depending on how they hold the accent. So Eugene was actually correcting it 
to be pronounced correctly, and the guy misunderstood it as him asking 
"when". 

I'm not trying to ruin the joke by explaining it, it's just that I didn't 
know that at first, and the first time I saw the name Nguyen, I thought it 
was pronounced like that too and wouldn't have guessed it was pronounced 
"Wen" or "Win," so in case there's anyone else here who didn't know and 
didn't get that part, there you go.﻿
